p: Another strong homophily variable in our results, co-residence, suggests another way to increase the resilience of medicinal plant knowledge. Globally, urban populations are increasing, including populations of Indigenous peoples [ 105]. As urbanization increases population density, there may be more opportunities for sharing ecological knowledge. However, one of the main challenges for sharing ecological knowledge in urban areas is the lack of natural resources [ 25]. Thus, government policies that increase urban plant quantity, diversity, non-toxic management, legality of sustainable harvest, and accessibility, such as landscaping, urban forests, school gardens, and community gardens, will support continued transmission of ecological knowledge in a future of increasing urbanization [ 106, 107].
